page.title: 06Mining in Silverdale
page.content: The 4 shafts at Silverdale Colliery are well over 100 years old,but mining has been going on in the area for more than 200 years.The earliest evidence of mine workings in Silverdale was the finding of fossils in the coah shales by Sir Robert Eggerton in 1763.Coal was mined in Silverdale in 1830 to provide fuel for the iron works.There has been only one major disaster at Silverdale,when 19 men were killed in a gas explosion underground.A unique feature of today's pit is the water purification plant which treats polluted water and makes clean water at a rate of 400 gallons a minute.In May 1976,the National Coal Board approved a scheme costing twenty million pounds to sink a new mine at Silverdale which will last for the next 50 years.860 men work at Silverdale pit many of them live in the village.They start work at 16 and retire at 60 or 65
